instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1707: What is A1707? A1707 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Late 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3072, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00281, 820-00928..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PP20V_USBC: What is PP20V_USBC? 20 volt power rail that comes directly from the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC1: What is USBC_XB_CC1? USBC_XB_CC1 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_XB_CC2: What is USBC_XB_CC2? USBC_XB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.USBC_TB_CC2: What is USBC_TB_CC2? USBC_TB_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
Hello
I am new to this forum. My name is Marcin and i work a electric repair shop in Poland. I am new to MacBook repairs and have lot of knowledge to complete. As for now i have a MacBook pro model <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1707</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 that wont start.
I can see under my microscope that someone soldered the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
I put the chip down again. I know I have a problem with the PP1V1 line nad <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> (0,017v, 0,402 diode-mode) but I don't know which chargers to replace . Can you please guide me were to check

I checked
Supply/LDO Rails - Diode Tests:

UB300
CB300: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.331
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.415V
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL>: on CB308: 3.385v, diode-mode: 0,492
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on CB306: 1.805v, diode-mode: 0,502
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TA_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on CB305: 1.802v, diode-mode: 0,466
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: na CB304: 1,124v only in one USB port, diode-mode:  0,483

UB400
CB400: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.331
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.416V
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL>: on CB408: 3.383v, diode-mode: 0,486
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on CB406: 1.803v, diode-mode: 0,502
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on CB405: 1.792v, diode-mode: 0,467
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: na CB404: 0v always, diode-mode: 0,484

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<CAPACITOR>C3100</CAPACITOR>: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.332
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.415V
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3108</CAPACITOR>: 3.383v, diode-mode: 0,486
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3106</CAPACITOR>: 1.815V, diode-mode: 0,504
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XA_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3105</CAPACITOR>: 1.799v, diode-mode: 0,469
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3104</CAPACITOR>: 1.118 only in one USB port, , diode-mode: 0,486

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>
<CAPACITOR>C3200</CAPACITOR>: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.331
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.414V
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3208</CAPACITOR>: 3.377v, diode-mode: 0,489
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR>: 1.802v, diode-mode: 0,502
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3205</CAPACITOR>: 1.798V, diode-mode: 0,469
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on <CAPACITOR>C3204</CAPACITOR>: 1.120 only in one USB port,, diode-mode: 0,485

<SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC</SIGNAL> 5.2V only where the charger is connected

I think I need to replace the UB400. I'm right ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

<SIGNAL>1V1_LDO</SIGNAL> must appear only at the powered port.
Looks like the problem is on UB400 area.

BTW, <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is the same power rail over entire board.
Do not waste time measuring it on different points.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message: Thanks for the advice. Reballing UB400 didn't help. I measured the voltage on the pin CB404 (without capacitor). I'm ordering a new CD3215C.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message: I have replaced UB400 twice and still don't have 1.1 line. Any ideas ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message: I swapped UB300 with UB400 and still no voltage on UB400. usb-c port is ok

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message: 1V1 LDO should appear only when connect the charger to corresponding port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message: I now. UB400 is the only one with no power  when the charger is connected. I noticed that the voltage does not restart in one usb-c input but still no 1.1v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
Did you get all 1V1 LDO correctly, before changing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip?
Which port restarts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
no, I didn't:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: on CB404 [QUOTE] 
UB400
CB400: <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: Diode-Mode: 0.331
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.416V
Diode Test on LDO Rails:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TB_LDO</SIGNAL>: on CB408: 3.383v, diode-mode: 0,486
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOA</SIGNAL>: on CB406: 1.803v, diode-mode: 0,502
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_TB_LDOD</SIGNAL>: on CB405: 1.792v, diode-mode: 0,467
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_TA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>: na CB404: 0v always, diode-mode: 0,484
[/QUOTE]
Not  restarting on bottom usb-c on the left side (UB400)
Should i replace  TBT ROM, UB090 for UB400 ??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message: So one port steady 5V and 3 ports restarting?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
Usually restarts means the problem is not on the corresponding port.
Board tries to start and SMC detects some error and blcok the power on sequence.
But you should first locate the problem on the port with fixed 5V.

Remove USB-C connector from the shell (for corresponding port) and inspect the pins.
Compare diode mode readings around UB400 and another working <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> area.
Pay atention to CC1/2 pins and input fuse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
CC1/2 is the same everywhere around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (UB300 UB400 <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>) 
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC1</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,580
<SIGNAL>USBC_XB_CC2</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,580
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,584
<SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC2</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,579
<SIGNAL>USBC_TB_CC1</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,572
<SIGNAL>USBC_TB_CC2</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,580
<SIGNAL>USBC_TA_CC1</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,570
<SIGNAL>USBC_TA_CC2</SIGNAL> diode-mode: 0,574

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
Values look good, but something else should be bad around UB400; if that is the fixed 5V port.

In theory, UB090 should be good, as it is used by UB300 to boot.
UB400 boots later from UB300.
But you can try to change it, or reflash, just in case.
Be sure to make a backup of its content.

Check all resistors around UB400 and from page 103.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
threads.message:
Thank you for your answer. 
Today I will reflash UB090
I will check the resistors later. Im  using the scheme <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> if someone has exactly <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-04 No power
